DOC.brief_summary: The aim of this study is to determine whether giving extra arginine, a simple amino acid, to patients with sickle cell disease seeking treatment for a pain crisis (vaso-occlusive painful events (VOE) will decrease pain scores, decrease the need for pain medications or decrease length of hospital stay or emergency department visit. Funding Source - FDA OOPD.
DOC.brief_title: Arginine Therapy for Sickle Cell Disease Pain
DOC.detailed_description: The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of IV L-arginine hydrochloride therapy in children with sickle cell disease (SCD) and vaso-occlusive pain events (VOE). Specifically, the impact on total opioid use (mg/kg) over the duration of their emergency department (ED) visit and hospital stay will be evaluated.
DOC.criteria: Established diagnosis of sickle cell disease (SCD); all genotypes Pain requiring medical care in an acute care setting (such as the emergency department or ED, hospital ward, day hospital, clinic) not attributable to nonsickle cell causes, that is moderatetosevere requiring parenteral opioids Clinical Failure for pain to sufficiently respond to 3 doses of parenteral opioids in the acute care setting OR decision to admit for continued pain management Hemoglobin less than 5 gm/dL or immediate need for red cell transfusion anticipated within next 12 hours Hepatic dysfunction of SGPT greater than 3 times the upper value Renal dysfunction of creatinine greater than 1.0 Mental status or neurological changes Acute stroke or clinical concern for stroke Pregnancy Allergy to arginine ED visit for VOE within 48 hours Hospitalization within 14 days Previous randomization in this arginine RCT (patient consented and screen failed before receiving study drug or placebo remains eligible for future participation).
